Given two tables as below, write a query to display the comparison result (higher/lower/same) of the average salary of employees in a department to the company's average salary.


drop table salary;
Create table salary(Id int,employee_id int,amount int,pay_date date);
insert into salary values(1,1,9000,'2017-03-31');
insert into salary values(2,2,6000,'2017-03-31');
insert into salary values(3,3,10000,'2017-03-31');
insert into salary values(4,1,7000,'2017-02-28');
insert into salary values(5,2,6000,'2017-02-28');
insert into salary values(6,3,8000,'2017-02-28');

drop table employee
Create table employee(Id int,department_id int);
insert into employee values(1,1);
insert into employee values(2,2);
insert into employee values(3,2);

Table: salary
| id | employee_id | amount | pay_date   |
|----|-------------|--------|------------|
| 1  | 1           | 9000   | 2017-03-31 |
| 2  | 2           | 6000   | 2017-03-31 |
| 3  | 3           | 10000  | 2017-03-31 |
| 4  | 1           | 7000   | 2017-02-28 |
| 5  | 2           | 6000   | 2017-02-28 |
| 6  | 3           | 8000   | 2017-02-28 |

The employee_id column refers to the employee_id in the following table employee.
| employee_id | department_id |
|-------------|---------------|
| 1           | 1             |
| 2           | 2             |
| 3           | 2             |

So for the sample data above, the result is:


| pay_month | department_id | comparison  |
|-----------|---------------|-------------|
| 2017-03   | 1             | higher      |
| 2017-03   | 2             | lower       |
| 2017-02   | 1             | same        |
| 2017-02   | 2             | same        |


Explanation


In March, the company's average salary is (9000+6000+10000)/3 = 8333.33...

Â 

The average salary for department '1' is 9000, which is the salary ofÂ employee_idÂ '1' since there is only one employee in this department. So the comparison result is 'higher' since 9000 > 8333.33 obviously.

Â 

The average salary of department '2' is (6000 + 10000)/2 = 8000, which is the average ofÂ employee_idÂ '2' and '3'. So the comparison result is 'lower' since 8000 < 8333.33.

Â 

With he same formula for the average salary comparison in February, the result is 'same' since both the department '1' and '2' have the same average salary with the company, which is 7000.
